PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  Project preparatory technical assistance is required to (i) assess technical feasibility, and 
financial and economic viability of proposed investments; (ii) define the scope of work and 
phasing of the investment; and (iii) prepare all documents required for ADB and governments 
approval of the loan. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  Preliminary structural, hydraulic and geological assessments. Review of availability 
and quality of available data, though desk study. In case of missing data, surveys will be carried 
out to collect data. In case of missing data that does affect the rehabilitation of the remaining 
aqueducts, the consultants will formulate terms of reference (TOR) for additional surveys. The 
consultants will establish the priority investment plan.  
 
3.  Project preparation reports and feasibility studies for the Project in accordance 
with  ADB’s  requirements  for  rehabilitation  of  the  priority  works. The feasibility  study 
includes  a  review  of  alternative  construction  methods,  materials,  etc  to  be  used  for  the 
rehabilitation, followed  by  a  selection  of most  appropriate  method  and/or  materials. These 
criteria  will  include,  but  is  not  limited  to,  technical,  financial  (life  cycle  costing),  social 
(affordability) and environmental (climate resilience) issues. The feasibility study will include 
financial and economic analysis of the proposed investment. 
 
4.  Supporting  studies  and  reports.  These  include:  (i)  socio-economic  impact 
assessment; (ii)  initial environmental  examination; (iii)  safeguard reviews,  if  applicable;  (iv) 
financial management capacity assessment of Metropolitan Waterworks and Sewerage System; 
and  (v)  procurement  capacity  assessment  of  MWSS.  The  resulting  reports  should  include 
recommendations for remedial measures and TORs for capacity development.  
 
5.  Water  safety,  risk  and  asset  management  plan.  The  plan  should  identify  non-
structural (such as organization set up, preparation of asset register, capacity development, real 
time monitoring system, etc) and structural measures (re-configuration and/or interconnection of 
aqueducts and/or settling basins, modification of intakes, construction of additional tunnel, etc). 
The structural modeling of the complete transmission system, to simulate severe earthquake 
scenarios is part of the risk management.  
 
6.  Overall implementation plan. This plan follows ADB’s project administration manual 
template, and includes description of the scope of the works, the implementation arrangements, 
the cost estimates and the procurement plan.

C.  Cost Estimates and Proposed Financing Arrangement

ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-others).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, provision of office space, communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented

D.  Consulting Services 
9.  ADB will contract a consulting firm to provide specialized services through a team of 
international  and  national  consultants.  The  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time), using the fixed budget selection method and full technical proposals.

10.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  key  consultants  of  the  project  preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) team are described in paras. 11 to 16.  
 
11.  Water Supply/Resources Specialist (Team Leader) (international 6 PMs, national 12 
PMs).  These  specialists  will  review,  update  and  improve  all  relevant  technical  documents 
required for loan processing, including relevant sections of the Report and Recommendation of 
the President (RRP). The international water supply specialist will be the team leader and 
responsible for the overall outcome of this PPTA. 
 
12.  The  experts  must  have  graduate  degree  in  water  supply  and/or  water  resources 
management or equivalent. He/she must have at least 15 years experience in the engineering 
design, construction, operation and management of a water distribution utility. He/she should 
also have experience and knowledge of preparing water safety plans.  
 
13.  Structural Engineers (international 5 PMs, national 10 PMs). These specialists are 
responsible for technical design of rehabilitation and earthquake proofing of the transmission 
system, and preparation of the relevant documents and design drawings. The international 
specialist will be responsible for the seismic vulnerability analysis and seismic strengthening of 
steel and concrete structures. 
 
14.  The experts must be licensed civil-structural engineer, holder of a master’s degree in 
structural engineering, and member and a duly-certified/recognized specialist of the Association

Appendix 4  13 
of Structural Engineers of the Philippines or a member of an internationally-known structural 
engineering association. With actual and extensive practice/experience in structural engineering 
and must have at least 15 years experience in their respective field of work, including structural 
and engineering design and/or computer modeling-analysis of all types of structures. 
 
15.  Financial  expert/economist  (national  5  PMs).  The  expert  will  provide  a  detailed 
financial and economic analysis of the proposed Project and the sub-projects. The consultant’s 
tasks include, but are not limited to the following: (i) prepare detailed project cost estimates; (ii) 
conduct in-depth financial and economic analysis of the investments; (iii) design the project 
fund-flow mechanism; (iv) undertake a financial management assessment of MWSS and the 
concessionaires; and (v) review tariff and consumers affordability implications. 
 
16.  The  expert  has  extensive  experience  in  public  sector  finance,  financial/cash  flow 
modeling and risk analysis for water supply projects. He/she is required to hold a graduate 
degree qualification in economics or business management with at least 15 years experience in 
undertaking financial and economic analysis of public and private sector organizations. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The executing agency of the TA is MWSS which will establish a project management 
unit with representatives of MWSS’ concessionaries. MWSS will finance the cost of office space 
and furniture for the consultants, and remuneration, per diem and transport of the counterpart 
staff.  Disbursements  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).
